Recap

  • General setting:

    1. Define a list of models. That is, let ΓΓ be the "finite" set of different possible models.

    2. Each model γγ is in ΓΓ, including the "true" model. Also, let θγθγ represent the parameters in model γγ.

    3. Put a prior over the set ΓΓ. Let Πγ=Pr[γ]Πγ=Pr[γ], for all γ∈Γγ∈Γ. Most common choice is the uniform prior, that is, Πγ=1#ΓΠγ=1#Γ, for all γ∈Γγ∈Γ, where #Γ#Γ is the total number of models in ΓΓ.

4 / 29

Recap

  • General setting:

    1. Define a list of models. That is, let ΓΓ be the "finite" set of different possible models.

    2. Each model γγ is in ΓΓ, including the "true" model. Also, let θγθγ represent the parameters in model γγ.

    3. Put a prior over the set ΓΓ. Let Πγ=Pr[γ]Πγ=Pr[γ], for all γ∈Γγ∈Γ. Most common choice is the uniform prior, that is, Πγ=1#ΓΠγ=1#Γ, for all γ∈Γγ∈Γ, where #Γ#Γ is the total number of models in ΓΓ.

    4. Put a prior on the parameters in each model, that is, each π(θγ)π(θγ).

    5. Compute marginal posterior probabilities Pr[γ|Y]Pr[γ|Y] for each model.

6 / 29

Recap

  • How should we choose the Bayes optimal model?

  • If loss function is

    L(^γ,γ)=1(^γ≠γ),L(γ^,γ)=1(γ^≠γ),

    that is,

    1. Loss equals zero if the correct model is chosen; and
    2. Loss equals one if incorrect model is chosen.
6 / 29

Recap

  • How should we choose the Bayes optimal model?

  • If loss function is

    L(^γ,γ)=1(^γ≠γ),L(γ^,γ)=1(γ^≠γ),

    that is,

    1. Loss equals zero if the correct model is chosen; and
    2. Loss equals one if incorrect model is chosen.

  • Then, selecting the model with the largest posterior probability minimizes the corresponding Bayes risk.

6 / 29

Recap

  • How should we choose the Bayes optimal model?

  • If loss function is

    L(^γ,γ)=1(^γ≠γ),L(γ^,γ)=1(γ^≠γ),

    that is,

    1. Loss equals zero if the correct model is chosen; and
    2. Loss equals one if incorrect model is chosen.

  • Then, selecting the model with the largest posterior probability minimizes the corresponding Bayes risk.

  • If goal is prediction, then

    p(yn+1|Y=(y1,…,yn))=∑γ∈Γ^Πγ⋅p(yn+1|Y,γ),p(yn+1|Y=(y1,…,yn))=∑γ∈ΓΠ^γ⋅p(yn+1|Y,γ),

    which is known as Bayesian model averaging (BMA).

7 / 29

Back to Bayesian linear regression

  • So what does this mean specifically in the context of linear regression?

  • First, recall that for model γγ, the posterior probability that the model is the right model is

    ^Πγ=ΠγLγ(Y)∑γ⋆∈ΓΠγ⋆Lγ⋆(Y).Π^γ=ΠγLγ(Y)∑γ⋆∈ΓΠγ⋆Lγ⋆(Y).

  • Practical issues

    • We need to calculate marginal likelihoods for ALL models in ΓΓ.

    • In general for, we cannot calculate the marginal likelihoods unless we have a proper or conjugate priors.

    • For linear regression, that would mean looking to priors like Zellner's g-prior, the horseshoe prior you were introduced to in the lab, and so on.

Bayesian variable selection

  • To explore Bayesian variable selection, rewrite each model γ∈Γγ∈Γ as

    Y∼Nn(Xγβγ,σ2In×n).Y∼Nn(Xγβγ,σ2In×n).

    • γj=1γj=1 means the jj'th predictor is included in the model, but γj=0γj=0 means it is not;

Bayesian variable selection

  • To explore Bayesian variable selection, rewrite each model γ∈Γγ∈Γ as

    Y∼Nn(Xγβγ,σ2In×n).Y∼Nn(Xγβγ,σ2In×n).

  • γγ represents the set of predictors we want to throw into our model.

  • Using the notation as before, each γ=(γ0,γ1,…,γp−1)∈{0,1}pγ=(γ0,γ1,…,γp−1)∈{0,1}p, so that the cardinality of ΓΓ is 2p2p, that is, the number of models in ΓΓ.

  • That is,

    • γj=1γj=1 means the jj'th predictor is included in the model, but γj=0γj=0 means it is not;
    • XγXγ is the matrix of predictors with γj=1γj=1;
    • βγβγ is the corresponding vector of predictors with γj=1γj=1.

  • Set pγ=∑pj=1γjpγ=∑j=1pγj, so that pγpγ is the number of predictors included in model γγ, then XγXγ is n×pγn×pγ and βγβγ is pγ×1pγ×1.

Bayesian variable selection

  • The outline for variable selection would be as follows:

    1. Write down likelihood under model γγ. That is,

      p(y|X,γ,βγ,σ2)∝(σ2)−n2 exp{−12σ2(y−Xγβγ)T(y−Xγβγ)}p(y|X,γ,βγ,σ2)∝(σ2)−n2 exp{−12σ2(y−Xγβγ)T(y−Xγβγ)}

Bayesian variable selection

  • With those pieces, the conditional posteriors are straightforward.

  • We can then compute marginal posterior probabilities Pr[γ|Y]Pr[γ|Y] for each model and select model with the highest posterior probability.

  • We can also compute posterior Pr[γj|Y]Pr[γj|Y], the posterior probability of including the jj'the predictor, often called marginal inclusion probability (MIP), allowing for uncertainty in the other predictors.

11 / 29

Bayesian variable selection

  • With those pieces, the conditional posteriors are straightforward.

  • We can then compute marginal posterior probabilities Pr[γ|Y]Pr[γ|Y] for each model and select model with the highest posterior probability.

  • We can also compute posterior Pr[γj|Y]Pr[γj|Y], the posterior probability of including the jj'the predictor, often called marginal inclusion probability (MIP), allowing for uncertainty in the other predictors.

  • Also straightforward to do model averaging once we have all posterior samples.

11 / 29

Bayesian variable selection

  • With those pieces, the conditional posteriors are straightforward.

  • We can then compute marginal posterior probabilities Pr[γ|Y]Pr[γ|Y] for each model and select model with the highest posterior probability.

  • We can also compute posterior Pr[γj|Y]Pr[γj|Y], the posterior probability of including the jj'the predictor, often called marginal inclusion probability (MIP), allowing for uncertainty in the other predictors.

  • Also straightforward to do model averaging once we have all posterior samples.

  • The Hoff book works through one example and you can find the Gibbs sampler for doing inference there. I strongly recommend you go through it carefully!

11 / 29

Bayesian variable selection

  • With those pieces, the conditional posteriors are straightforward.

  • We can then compute marginal posterior probabilities Pr[γ|Y]Pr[γ|Y] for each model and select model with the highest posterior probability.

  • We can also compute posterior Pr[γj|Y]Pr[γj|Y], the posterior probability of including the jj'the predictor, often called marginal inclusion probability (MIP), allowing for uncertainty in the other predictors.

  • Also straightforward to do model averaging once we have all posterior samples.

  • The Hoff book works through one example and you can find the Gibbs sampler for doing inference there. I strongly recommend you go through it carefully!

  • In class however, let's focus on using R packages for doing the same.

12 / 29

Example

  • Health plans use many tools to try to control the cost of prescription medicines.

  • For older drugs, generic substitutes that are the equivalent to name-brand drugs are available at considerable savings.

  • Another tool that may lower costs is restricting drugs that the physician may prescribe.

  • For example if three similar drugs for treating the same condition are available, a health plan may require the physician to prescribe only one of them, allowing the plan to negotiate discounts based on a higher volume of sales.

12 / 29

Example

  • Health plans use many tools to try to control the cost of prescription medicines.

  • For older drugs, generic substitutes that are the equivalent to name-brand drugs are available at considerable savings.

  • Another tool that may lower costs is restricting drugs that the physician may prescribe.

  • For example if three similar drugs for treating the same condition are available, a health plan may require the physician to prescribe only one of them, allowing the plan to negotiate discounts based on a higher volume of sales.

  • We have data from 29 health plans can be used to explore the effectiveness of these two strategies in controlling drug costs.

12 / 29

Example

  • Health plans use many tools to try to control the cost of prescription medicines.

  • For older drugs, generic substitutes that are the equivalent to name-brand drugs are available at considerable savings.

  • Another tool that may lower costs is restricting drugs that the physician may prescribe.

  • For example if three similar drugs for treating the same condition are available, a health plan may require the physician to prescribe only one of them, allowing the plan to negotiate discounts based on a higher volume of sales.

  • We have data from 29 health plans can be used to explore the effectiveness of these two strategies in controlling drug costs.

  • The response is COST, the average cost of the prescriptions to the plan per day (in dollars).

12 / 29

Example

  • Potential explanatory variables are:
    • RXPM: Average number of prescriptions per member per year
    • GS: Percent generic substitute used by the plan
    • RI: Restrictiveness Index, from 0 (no restrictions) to 100 (total restrictions on the physician)
    • COPAY: Average member copay on prescriptions
    • AGE: Average member age
    • F: percent female members
    • MM: Member months, a measure of the size of the plan
    • ID: an identifier for the name of the plan
13 / 29

Example

  • Potential explanatory variables are:

    • RXPM: Average number of prescriptions per member per year
    • GS: Percent generic substitute used by the plan
    • RI: Restrictiveness Index, from 0 (no restrictions) to 100 (total restrictions on the physician)
    • COPAY: Average member copay on prescriptions
    • AGE: Average member age
    • F: percent female members
    • MM: Member months, a measure of the size of the plan
    • ID: an identifier for the name of the plan

  • Since we do not have so many data points, let's use Bayesian model selection and model averaging to explore the relationship of GS and RI to COST, adjusting for the other variables.

13 / 29

Example

  • Potential explanatory variables are:

    • RXPM: Average number of prescriptions per member per year
    • GS: Percent generic substitute used by the plan
    • RI: Restrictiveness Index, from 0 (no restrictions) to 100 (total restrictions on the physician)
    • COPAY: Average member copay on prescriptions
    • AGE: Average member age
    • F: percent female members
    • MM: Member months, a measure of the size of the plan
    • ID: an identifier for the name of the plan

  • Since we do not have so many data points, let's use Bayesian model selection and model averaging to explore the relationship of GS and RI to COST, adjusting for the other variables.

  • The data is in the file costs.txt on Sakai.

Introduction

16 / 29

Introduction

  • So far in this course, inference has been made "relatively" easy with conjugate and semi-conjugate priors.

  • As we have seen, under conjugate or semi-conjugate priors, posteriors can be approximated with the Monte Carlo method or Gibbs sampler.

  • However, sometimes a conjugate prior is unavailable or undesirable!

  • In such cases, the full conditional distributions of parameters often have no standard form, and Gibbs sampling cannot be easily used.

16 / 29

Introduction

  • So far in this course, inference has been made "relatively" easy with conjugate and semi-conjugate priors.

  • As we have seen, under conjugate or semi-conjugate priors, posteriors can be approximated with the Monte Carlo method or Gibbs sampler.

  • However, sometimes a conjugate prior is unavailable or undesirable!

  • In such cases, the full conditional distributions of parameters often have no standard form, and Gibbs sampling cannot be easily used.

  • So what can we do?

16 / 29

Introduction

  • So far in this course, inference has been made "relatively" easy with conjugate and semi-conjugate priors.

  • As we have seen, under conjugate or semi-conjugate priors, posteriors can be approximated with the Monte Carlo method or Gibbs sampler.

  • However, sometimes a conjugate prior is unavailable or undesirable!

  • In such cases, the full conditional distributions of parameters often have no standard form, and Gibbs sampling cannot be easily used.

  • So what can we do?

  • Metropolis and Metropolis-Hastings algorithms provide a generic method of approximating the posterior distribution corresponding to any combination of prior and data model.

  • Then as usual, we are interested in

17 / 29

Introduction

  • As a refresher, suppose Y∼π(y|θ)Y∼π(y|θ) and suppose we specify a prior π(θ)π(θ) on θθ.

  • Then as usual, we are interested in

    π(θ|y)=π(θ)L(y;θ)L(y).π(θ|y)=π(θ)L(y;θ)L(y).

  • As we already know, the challenge is that it is often difficult to compute L(y)L(y).

  • Using the Monte Carlo method or Gibbs sampler, we have seen that we don't need to know L(y)L(y). As long as we have conjugate and semi-conjugate priors, we can generate samples directly from π(θ|y)π(θ|y).

Introduction

  • As a refresher, suppose Y∼π(y|θ)Y∼π(y|θ) and suppose we specify a prior π(θ)π(θ) on θθ.

  • Then as usual, we are interested in

    π(θ|y)=π(θ)L(y;θ)L(y).π(θ|y)=π(θ)L(y;θ)L(y).

  • As we already know, the challenge is that it is often difficult to compute L(y)L(y).

  • Using the Monte Carlo method or Gibbs sampler, we have seen that we don't need to know L(y)L(y). As long as we have conjugate and semi-conjugate priors, we can generate samples directly from π(θ|y)π(θ|y).

  • So again, the question is, what happens if we cannot sample directly from π(θ|y)π(θ|y)?

Metropolis algorithm

  • If r>1r>1

    • Action: set θ(s+1)=θ⋆θ(s+1)=θ⋆

Metropolis algorithm

  • This is the basic intuition behind the Metropolis algorithm.

  • Where should the proposed value θ⋆θ⋆ come from?

  • Sample θ⋆θ⋆ close to the current value θ(s)θ(s) using a symmetric proposal distribution g[θ⋆|θ(s)]g[θ⋆|θ(s)]. gg is actually a "family of proposal distributions", indexed by the specific value of θ(s)θ(s).

  • Here, symmetric means that g[θ⋆|θ(s)]=g[θ(s)|θ⋆]g[θ⋆|θ(s)]=g[θ(s)|θ⋆].

  • The symmetric proposal is usually very simple with density concentrated near θ(s)θ(s), for example, N(θ⋆;θ(s),δ2)N(θ⋆;θ(s),δ2) or Unif(θ⋆;θ(s)−δ,θ(s)+δ)Unif(θ⋆;θ(s)−δ,θ(s)+δ).

  • After obtaining θ⋆θ⋆, either add it or add a copy of θ(s)θ(s) to our current set of values, depending on the value of rr.

    1. Given θ(1),…,θ(s)θ(1),…,θ(s), generate a candidate value θ⋆∼g[θ⋆|θ(s)]θ⋆∼g[θ⋆|θ(s)].

Metropolis algorithm

  • Once we obtain the samples, then we are back to using Monte Carlo approximations for quantities of interest.

  • That is, we can again approximate posterior means, quantiles, and other quantities of interest using the empirical distribution of our sampled values.

  • Some notes:

25 / 29

Metropolis algorithm

  • Once we obtain the samples, then we are back to using Monte Carlo approximations for quantities of interest.

  • That is, we can again approximate posterior means, quantiles, and other quantities of interest using the empirical distribution of our sampled values.

  • Some notes:

    • The Metropolis chain ALWAYS moves to the proposed θ⋆θ⋆ at iteration s+1s+1 if θ⋆θ⋆ has higher target density than the current θ(s)θ(s).

    • Sometimes, it also moves to a θ⋆θ⋆ value with lower density in proportion to the density value itself.

25 / 29

Metropolis algorithm

  • Once we obtain the samples, then we are back to using Monte Carlo approximations for quantities of interest.

  • That is, we can again approximate posterior means, quantiles, and other quantities of interest using the empirical distribution of our sampled values.

  • Some notes:

    • The Metropolis chain ALWAYS moves to the proposed θ⋆θ⋆ at iteration s+1s+1 if θ⋆θ⋆ has higher target density than the current θ(s)θ(s).

    • Sometimes, it also moves to a θ⋆θ⋆ value with lower density in proportion to the density value itself.

    • This leads to a random, Markov process than naturally explores the space according to the probability defined by π(θ|y)π(θ|y), and hence generates a sequence that, while dependent, eventually represents draws from π(θ|y)π(θ|y).

Metropolis algorithm: convergence

  • We will not cover the convergence theory behind Metropolis chains in detail, but below are a few notes for those interested:

    • The Markov process generated under this condition is ergodic and has a limiting distribution.

    • Here, think of ergodicity as meaning that the chain can move anywhere at each step, which is ensured, for example, if g[θ⋆|θ(s)]>0g[θ⋆|θ(s)]>0 everywhere!

26 / 29

Metropolis algorithm: convergence

  • We will not cover the convergence theory behind Metropolis chains in detail, but below are a few notes for those interested:

    • The Markov process generated under this condition is ergodic and has a limiting distribution.

    • Here, think of ergodicity as meaning that the chain can move anywhere at each step, which is ensured, for example, if g[θ⋆|θ(s)]>0g[θ⋆|θ(s)]>0 everywhere!

    • By construction, it turns out that the Metropolis chains are reversible, so that convergence to π(θ|y)π(θ|y) is assured.

26 / 29

Metropolis algorithm: convergence

  • We will not cover the convergence theory behind Metropolis chains in detail, but below are a few notes for those interested:

    • The Markov process generated under this condition is ergodic and has a limiting distribution.

    • Here, think of ergodicity as meaning that the chain can move anywhere at each step, which is ensured, for example, if g[θ⋆|θ(s)]>0g[θ⋆|θ(s)]>0 everywhere!

    • By construction, it turns out that the Metropolis chains are reversible, so that convergence to π(θ|y)π(θ|y) is assured.

    • Think of reversibility as being equivalent to symmetry of the joint density of two consecutive θ(s)θ(s) and θ(s+1)θ(s+1) in the stationary process, which we do have by using a symmetric proposal distribution.

26 / 29

Metropolis algorithm: convergence

  • We will not cover the convergence theory behind Metropolis chains in detail, but below are a few notes for those interested:

    • The Markov process generated under this condition is ergodic and has a limiting distribution.

    • Here, think of ergodicity as meaning that the chain can move anywhere at each step, which is ensured, for example, if g[θ⋆|θ(s)]>0g[θ⋆|θ(s)]>0 everywhere!

    • By construction, it turns out that the Metropolis chains are reversible, so that convergence to π(θ|y)π(θ|y) is assured.

    • Think of reversibility as being equivalent to symmetry of the joint density of two consecutive θ(s)θ(s) and θ(s+1)θ(s+1) in the stationary process, which we do have by using a symmetric proposal distribution.

  • If you want to learn more about convergence of MCMC chains, consider taking one of the courses on stochastic processes, or Markov chain theory.

26 / 29

Metropolis algorithm: tuning

  • Correlation between samples can be adjusted by selecting optimal δδ (i.e., spread of the distribution) in the proposal distribution
27 / 29

Metropolis algorithm: tuning

  • Correlation between samples can be adjusted by selecting optimal δδ (i.e., spread of the distribution) in the proposal distribution

  • Decreasing correlation increases the effective sample size, increasing rate of convergence, and improving the Monte Carlo approximation to the posterior.

27 / 29

Metropolis algorithm: tuning

  • Correlation between samples can be adjusted by selecting optimal δδ (i.e., spread of the distribution) in the proposal distribution

  • Decreasing correlation increases the effective sample size, increasing rate of convergence, and improving the Monte Carlo approximation to the posterior.

  • However,

    • δδ too small leads to r≈1r≈1 for most proposed values, a high acceptance rate, but very small moves, leading to highly correlated chain.
    • δδ too large can get "stuck" at the posterior mode(s) because θ⋆θ⋆ can get very far away from the mode, leading to a very low acceptance rate and again high correlation in the Markov chain.
27 / 29

Metropolis algorithm: tuning

  • Correlation between samples can be adjusted by selecting optimal δδ (i.e., spread of the distribution) in the proposal distribution

  • Decreasing correlation increases the effective sample size, increasing rate of convergence, and improving the Monte Carlo approximation to the posterior.

  • However,

    • δδ too small leads to r≈1r≈1 for most proposed values, a high acceptance rate, but very small moves, leading to highly correlated chain.
    • δδ too large can get "stuck" at the posterior mode(s) because θ⋆θ⋆ can get very far away from the mode, leading to a very low acceptance rate and again high correlation in the Markov chain.

  • Thus, good to implement several short runs of the algorithm varying δδ and settle on one that yields acceptance rate in the range of 25-50%.

27 / 29

Metropolis algorithm: tuning

  • Correlation between samples can be adjusted by selecting optimal δδ (i.e., spread of the distribution) in the proposal distribution

  • Decreasing correlation increases the effective sample size, increasing rate of convergence, and improving the Monte Carlo approximation to the posterior.

  • However,

    • δδ too small leads to r≈1r≈1 for most proposed values, a high acceptance rate, but very small moves, leading to highly correlated chain.
    • δδ too large can get "stuck" at the posterior mode(s) because θ⋆θ⋆ can get very far away from the mode, leading to a very low acceptance rate and again high correlation in the Markov chain.

  • Thus, good to implement several short runs of the algorithm varying δδ and settle on one that yields acceptance rate in the range of 25-50%.

  • Burn-in is even more important here!
